Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>Input:There are 5 kittens and 4 bowls of kitten food. There are 3 apples and 6 plates of catnip. How many kittens get food? Choices:   A: I don’t know the answer.  B: 2 kittens get food C: 5 kittens get food D: 1 kitten gets food E: all 5 kittens  get food F: 3 kittens get food G: 4 kittens get food<n><n>### Response<n>Response:D<n><n>### Input <n>Input:  There are 3 pennies, 4 nickels, 3 dimes, and 3 quarters in a piggy bank.  How much money is in the bank?  Answer: 3<n><n>Input:  How many apples does one pear cost?   Answer: 2<n><n>### Input   One large apple costs 2 dollars.  Small apples cost 1 dollar.  Large apples cost 3 dollars.  Small appes cost 2 dollars.  How much does one medium apple cost? <n><n>### Response    B<n><n>The answer for each of the problems was the same:<n><n>* Two<n>* Four<n>* Five<n><n><h2>Answer for Day 1</h2><n><n><h2>"I don't know the answer" is not an answer<n><n><h2>(I can re-word it to make it more acceptable by changing the question, but I don't want to do that)<n><n><h2>\textit{I should have said D}<n><n></h2><n>

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a business restaurant likely to be located? Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		<n>- If the business is not at any of the specified locations, the response could say either at the business sector or in the yellow pages.<n>- You would not want to repeat any of the choices.<n>- The response should include at least two of the choices (one from each group), because a restaurant could be in both the business sector and the mall.<n>### Input:The new grocery store will be located on  St. Road. at which of the following intersections will it be located? Choice: A: intersection C: intersection E: intersection B: intersection D: intersection<n><n>### Response<n><n>- Include at least two of the intersections.<n>- It would be best to include at least two of each type.<n>- Repeat one of the types if there are more than two.<n>- Make sure you use the intersection letters and the intersections must be in order.<n>### Test:<n>#### Income Calculations<n>1. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option B<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If you need money.<n><n>### Input & Output:<n><n>>  Input:1 2 2<n>> <n>> Output:* 4<n>><n><n>### Explantation:<n><n>Factorial, where n! (read: n factorial) is the product of all positive integers less than or equal to n. So n!, or factorial n, is n * (n-1) * (n-2) *... * 3 * 2 * 1<n>Example:<n>input n=7, then n! = 7! = 7*6*5*4*3*2*1 = 210<n><n>### Explation :<n><n>We are using an if statement to make some decision, there will be a condition and one of the answers.<n><n><n>### What we tested:<n><n>### What is the expected runtime of this code in milliseconds (ms):<n><n>### How much memory is this code expected to require (in MB) :<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:To prevent any glare during the big football game he made sure to clean the dust of his what? Choices:  A: television B: attic C: corner D: they cannot clean corner and library during football match they cannot need that E: ground<n><n>### Response:		<n>```bash<n>#!/bin/bash<n># This is a program that uses the command read to read<n># the user's choice.  The user's choice is printed out to the screen.<n><n># Variables<n>read x    # a variable named x to store the user's input<n><n>## Declare a variable<n>### Declare intx;<n>### Declare floatx;<n>### etc...<n><n># Store a choice (e.g. "A", "B", etc) in var.<n># Variable that gets printed to the screen<n>var=$1<n><n># Print out the choice the user made (var)<n>echo -e "$var"<n><n>```<n><n>### Input and Response.<n><n>### Task: Write a text file that prints the following information in the format given.<n><n>### Input data:<n><n>```json<n>/*<n>{<n>    'x': 80,<n>    'y': 20<n>}<n>*/<n>```<n><n>## Input:<n>Write a program that when given a specific input will output a certain response. The input could be a string and response could be a single character.<n>

Input: 9<n>Input: Inflation on a product increases 10% during the annual sales cycle.  Which of the following is the correct inverse of 104? Choose all that apply. A: -54 B: 0.9 C: 0.1<n>**Demostration** : If that percentage increases from 104 to 114, then the inverse is 0.9. If that percentage decreases from 104, 102  or 100, then the inverse is -0.9.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>---<n>© 2020 Trilogy Education Services, a 2U, Inc. brand. All Rights Reserved.<n>

Recently in this company the managers realized that only half of their old phones that come in to the company were actually put back out in to the community for other to use. These old phones contain tons of useful metals that could be sold for a good price. All of the old phones that come into the company have a phone code on it that describes how much metals there are in the phone. This year the company is determined to sell all the phones they get in within these numbers to the highest bidder. It was decided that if the company could sell their phones within the phone codes then this will be considered recycling. The manager of the company decided on giving a price of $5/hour to the person putting the phones in to the program. Since they had some employees that could do the job some employees had to take cuts in hours to fit in the program. The manager did not have enough phones at the end of the day so he had to hire five part time employees to finish out the day. If the phones the part time employees got the manager wanted paid $32/hour. <n>The manager wants to determine how many of the original employees should be kept on after the program while making sure the program still goes forward. Each employee who was not able to keep their original hour amount will get hired as a part time employee.<n><n>### Assumptions:<n>Assumptions: I would think that a good assumption for this question would be that since the company is working towards recycling more phones because they have a new program

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is the only was to recover from exhaustion? Choices:  A: mediate B: have rest C: stay in bed D: run out of steam E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) mediate

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input/Output:<n>input: "Mary had 30 stickers."<n>output: "Mary has 7 stickers."<n><n>input: "How many stickers does Mary need for an even amount of stickers?"<n>output: "5"<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Use the variables in the statements below to answer the questions. <n><n>### Instance: The variables for a set are defined as follows: 1: set = {x, y, z}<n>Set = {x, y}<n>How many items are in set?<n><n>### Response<n>Set = {y}<n>There are 2 items in set.<n><n>How many objects are in set?<n>### Response<n><n>2<n><n>How many items in set contain x?<n>### Response:<n><n>z<n><n>How many items x contains?<n>### response:<n><n>set<n><n>### Instances:<n>3:  set = {a, b, y, z} <n><n>5:  set = {x,y,z} <n><n>7:  set = {z} <n><n>1:  set = {y}<n><n>### input:set = {x,y} <n><n>### output:<n><n>x<n><n>### Instructor:Write a sentence that answers the question.<n><n>## Instance:Set = {a, b}How many items in set are also items in set?<n>Response:1<n>## Instance: Set = {a, b};  Set = {x,y};  Set = {z} Which of the input sets are NOT subsets of the other input sets?  Response:  {z}<n>How many elements in  set are contained in  set?<n>Respons<n>1<n>How many elements in set are NOT part of set?<n>Response: 3<n>How many elements in the input sets are not in the output set? Response:set not in the output set:3<n>

Replace the underlined  pronoun(s)  with a proper pronoun for each sentence.<n><n>### Sample Statement:<n>I've found a good book, I'd share it with you but I  ____.<n><n>### Sample 1:<n>I've been to the mall more times this week than I normally do. I am going to try to  ____ some tonight.<n>You were in a bad accident, fortunately, they made you well again. Replace the underlined pronoun with a proper pronoun.<n><n>### Pronouns:<n>```1. I, me, my, mine, we, our, us, ours, you, your, yourselves, he, him, his, she, her, hers, it, its, that```<n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>I've found A  good book and I would share it A with you but

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where must one wear a white shoe? Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>I will answer option C, left foot.

True" )      <n>  ```

Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1. The instruction reads exactly as it appears in the document and as it appears in the instruction response.<n>2. The task should include a clear goal for the computer program, and it should show your understanding that the computer program is to fulfill that goal. <n>3. You should assume that the computer program begins on a blank page, and the given information contains everything it needs to complete its task. <n><n>### Demands:<n><n>1. Your response should be a functioning program.  <n>2. Your response should not have any input that is not given in the instructions.<n>3. Your program should be correct.  <n>4. Your code should clearly demonstrate a comprehension and understanding of how you're directing the computer to complete the task.<n>5. Your code should be indented.<n>6. Your code should be properly formatted.  <n>7. Your code should clearly indicate a division of labor.<n>8. Your code should not be redundant. <n><n>## Task: Write a single program that will read two positive integers, and divide them to equal the remainder as much as possible.  <n><n>1. When you've finished designing your program, save it to the folder under the name `Divisor.java`.<n><n>2. Double-click the program to compile it.  If the compilation is wrong, you can also run the JGrasp compiler.<n>3. Double-click on `Divisor.class`, and then click `Run`.  <n>4. Input 21 and 9 into the console and observe which value is returned.  <n>5. Compare your code to the following:<n><n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n>public class Divisor<n>{<n>	/**<n>	 * @param args the command line arguments<n>	 */<n>	public static void main(String[] args) <n>	{<n>		Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);<n><n>		int a = scan.nextInt();<n>		int b = scan.nextInt()<n>		scan.close();<n><n>		int c = math.divMod(a,b);<n><n>		System.out.print(c);<n>	}<n>}<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where will a bullet projectile be found during a war? Choices:  A: battle field B: museum C: weapon D: canon E: tornado<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is Option E:Tornado<n><n>### Instructions:Using a diagram, draw a solution path for a 10x10 Rubiks Cube. Provide 3 different path solutions.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>There are a few different path solutions to a 10x5 rubik's cube:<n>1. You could start with your center layer facing up, top layer to the left, and the right layer upside down(R/ U' R,R'/ U')<n>2. You could start with the middle two layers upside down(U U',U' L U)<n>3. You could start with all of the layers upside down(UL U' U' L U U' L U' U L)<n><n><n>### Response2:<n>There are a lot of different path solutions for a 10 x 10 rubik's cube. For example, you can make one layer upside down(U L), then do the R' R,R' R moves, then do the U' R, R' U' moves, and finally you can do the R' R',  R  moves, and finally you're done. You could also start with the outside layers facing up and then do the U' U, U' U moves, then the R' R' moves, then the R movies. You could also start the middle layer facing up and starting doing U' L, U B R' U moves, or U' L, B R' U, or U' L B R' U. Basically, the more complicated something gets, the more difficult it is to solve.<n><n>###Response 3<n>All there are three methods for solving a rubiks’ cube is:<n><n>###Method 3<n>There are two ways to solve a 10x3 rubik's cube, both involving the "cubicle" algorithm. This is how you solve it when the middle layer faces up and the outermost layer faces down.<n>First, turn your cube so that the middle layer faces down, and all other layers face up. Then do the steps "up' 'R' 'R'," "U' L' U' L", "R' 'L" and "U' U' U' L". After that, turn your cube so the the center layer is turned around and faces down again

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The obsessive man was always washing hands, he had even done it so much once that it caused a what? Choices:  A: use soap B: irritation C: cleanliness D: thinking E: wet towel<n><n>### Response:		E<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you find people gathered near liquid in a workplace? Choices:  A: water cooler B: opera C: hospital D: hockey game E: beach<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Input<n>A: water cooler B. opera C. hospital D. hockey game E. beach<n><n>### Output<n>E<n><n>## Solution<n>A workplace does not often involve entertainment or relaxing recreation. When people gather around a water cooler, they likely work there or are passing through a business. Opera, hospital, and hockey game all involve places to be and not somewhere to find relaxation.<n><n>Beach involves relaxation and it's common to find people gathered in this location for some time to spend leisure.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A workplace does involve locations where you find people. However, most workplaces are not leisure-like or places to spend any quality time. As a workplace environment, this question focuses on finding a work-related setting to find a location where people gather.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>```js<n>var answer = ['A', 'E', 'C'];<n>```<n><n>### Explanation: Open meadows are often areas with wild grass or other short, non-woody plants. An arctic tundra is one of the ecozones of the bioclimatic zone of the planet Earth. The tundra biome is found mainly north of the Arctic Circle from 60 to 70° latitude, in eastern Europe, in the North Asian subcontinent, in parts of the subarctic in North America, Greenland, Iceland, and Norway, and in the Fennoscandian archipelago. Finally, the sand dunes are the most recognizable feature of a beach. The most common type of sand dune is a barchan dune, which is a cone-shaped dune formed by the movement of wind-blown sand.<n><n>

Note: do not write the commands in the header.<n> * Imagine that you are playing a game on a computer that is similar to Sudoku. The game has various grids that are covered with numbers, and your job is to decide which number to place in each of the squares. However, in the game you are playing each game is only worth 1 point. You will need to get at least 50 points during the game to win. However, if a game is worth more than a total of 6 points, it will not be counted and the game will be lost. In each level, there is a certain amount of games you need to complete with a maximum of 30 games per level. Every time you complete a game you will win 50 points. Every game in a level will take you 80 actions to complete, but the number of actions you need to complete a game will be different in each level. Level 1 starts out easy because you only need to make 20 games in order to pass the game. However, as you move up in level, it becomes progressively more difficult. Level 7 will be the most difficult in which you must complete a whole level of games but will only get 80 actions. You need to think about how many times you are going to complete each of the lower level games for each level, and be sure to save in between each level in order to progress with the game. You will also want to track your progress along the way as you go. This game gives you a challenge because in this game the more points you win, the less often you will see points awarded for games that aren't going to be easy to compete. However, if you are to win the game, you eventually have to take the game that is worth 6 points or higher. In your instructions, you will need to write an algorithm that works as a loop that works through each game in each level with the parameters of:<n>  - 30 games to win 10

A: Ancient writing that was used to record scientific experiments done by the ancient Egyptians B: Ancient writing that looks like a series of wedges C: Ancient writing that is written in code D: Ancient writing that looked like hieroglyphics E: Ancient writing that used styluses instead of pens<n><n>### Response(c):<n>#### [D: Ancient writing that resembled hieroglyphics]<n>### Reason:Cuneiform is the earliest known writing system. It was used by the ancient Sumerians and Akkadians of Mesopotamia. Cuneiform is considered the first known form of writing in human history.<n><n>### Input:(14–16) How can using a spreadsheet help students with homework? Choices: 1: You cannot make mistakes. 2: It’s a free service. 3: They won’t have to calculate their homework. 4: It’s an easy way to keep track of homework.<n><n>### Response:(1,3,4)<n>#### [4: It's an easy way to track homework.]: It helps children keep track of their homework and remind them to do it.<n><n>###Input:Greece is the home of the Parthenon.<n><n>###Response:(C): It is the country that created it.<n><n>##### Input:<n>A. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5. Choices:  A: sophisticated B: imprevist C: arcane D: heavenly E: new<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Output:A new routine<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>Both of these are correct.<n><n>```python<n>if mary > 166:<n>    print("Zach saved up 65 dollars to buy a bike. He only needs to make 4 more to buy it!")"Mary has 89 stickers left"<n><n>```<n><n>```python<n>balance.save<n>balance is a list<n>```<n><n><n>## Review:<n><n>The list contains 8 objects.  Each object has the class.<n><n>`class` is called on the list so that each object has the same class.<n><n>The list has 8 objects with the class Bicycles.<n><n>Each object has a name, cost and description. You print the name and cost.<n><n><n>```python<n>a = [50, 60, 150, 100, 140, 90, 90]<n>print(f"Each number in the list: {a} is an item.")<n>print(f"You can print each item: {a[0]} and {a[1]} and {a[2]} each with the number and description of each item")<n>#f" print each item in the list with type" "<n>#f"you need f in quotes<n><n>```<n><n><n>```python <n>class Bicycles:<n>    name = input()<n>    cost = input()<n>    description = input()<n>    def save(self):<n>        balance = 0 #initialize the balance with 0<n>        for item in self:<n>            balance = balance + item.cost<n>        print(f"{self.name} saves \${balance} in the balance of 65 dollars.")<n>        print("The new balance is:", balance)<n>    <n>```<n><n>Answers:<n><n>You can also create your own class and write your own method!<n><n>```python<n>class Human:<n>    name = ''<n>    age = 17<n>    height = 5'3"<n>    def getInfo(self):<n>        print('You want my info?', self.name)<n>        print(self.height)<n><n>def printinfo (person1, person2):

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		Choice E. <n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### InputChoices: a) The sunset was so bright that the sunlight bounced off the water onto a boat far away. C: The light from the sun hit the water. b)The cat was sleeping all afternoon until he heard a noise and went running. C: went into the air. c) The child is crying, he is hungry right now. C: The bouncy ball flew into the air into the sky. d) The boat fell so low that the people on it were drowning. D: Ate the food right away.<n><n>### A)What's the difference between "on the surface" and "afloat"?<n><n>An object at the surface is floating. On the surface suggests more movement than afloat, e.g. "It appeared to be floating on the surface of the water."<n><n>### B)What does "airborne" mean?<n><n>Something airborne is floating - in the air. I think that your example was a typo, but see if it changes anything.<n><n>### C)How do you know the cat "hit" the water? It might only have glanced off the surface.<n><n>The word _hit_ conveys the meaning of hitting something. But there may never have been any contact.<n><n>### D)The child wasn't crying about being hungry - just _crying._<n>"Crying" suggests no more information.<n><n>### E)Explain why "the bouncy ball flewing into the air" is incorrect grammar.<n><n>Flying into the air is an incorrect formulation. "The bouncy ball flewed into the air" would only be correct if _flewed_ were the past tense of the verb _flee_.<n><n>### F)Explain why "drowning people on the boat" is incorrect.<n><n>When people are drowning on a boat, they are standing on the boat. Drowning conveys the meaning that someone is not standing on the boat any longer. But they could still be afloat - on the water.<n><n>### G)Explain why "crying child" is incorrect.<n>"The child was crying" - that's a complete sentence

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		B<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>(A)<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Please write pseudocode for a program to respond to each of the questions. Be sure to write pseudocode that is correct, complete, neat, and understandable.<n><n>### Sample Solution:<n>```<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions<n>var a = 1<n>var b = 19<n>var c = 4<n>var d = 20<n>var e = 15<n>var f = 20<n><n>1.If a * 2 is equal to 24, which integer is closest to the value of (a * 2)?<n>2.a/b = 0.4 then what is a and b?<n>3.If c is added to 5 then subtracted from 9 and then added to b, what is the answer?<n>4.If c * 2 is 186, what is c rounded to the nearest ten?<n>5.If b/a = c/5 what is the equivalent ration of d/b?<n>6.If d is subtracted from 26 and then divided by c what does the answer amount to?<n>7.The value of e is greater than the value of f<n>8.If b^2 = 20 b^7 = 1024<n>9.In the expression f / g what does the numerator amount to?<n>10.Sally was a senior student<n>```<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>Write pseudocode for a program that performs the task described in the prompt. In the task, you will be supplied questions, each of which contains a situation in which a math operation will be performed on two numbers. The first part of the solution will be answering one of those questions. The second part of the solution will consist of pseudocode for your program to perform these operations.<n><n>### Pseudocode: <n><n>```<n>Answer the question(s):<n><n>```<n>#1<n>answer = ((a * 2) - (2 * 4) + ( (a * 2) + (2 * 2))) or<n>answer is between 8-12 so answer = 10<n><n>#2<n>answer = ((a + b) + (b + c) + (c + d)) or<n>answer = 4<n>```<n><n>## Demo-Response:<n>```<n>

If you do not notify them, you'll get in trouble<n><n>**Answer choice C**<n>When you go longer than expected, it's still on time and you don't have to change any<n><n>**Answer choice D**<n><n>In case you go over, you must notify your client that you cannot finish the appointment on time. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What does moving cars entail? Choices:  A: driving B: road C: getting tired D: accidents E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def moving(cars):<n><n>    moving_cars = 0<n><n>    if cars == 'A':<n>        cars_moving = 1<n><n>    elif cars == 'B':<n>        cars_road = 1<n><n>        for item in cars_list:<n>            for item_number in cars_list:        <n>                if item_number['number'] == item_number['number_of_children'] + 1:<n>                    moving_cars += cars_child + 1<n><n>        cars_mov_add = moving_cars - cars_road<n>        moving_cars = cars_child<n>        cars_movement = moving_cars<n><n>    elif cars  == 'C':<n>        moving_c = 1<n>        moving_c_add = 1<n><n><n>    print(moving_c + moving_c_add)<n><n><n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would a person expect if they are competent in their school work? Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>[Passing grade]<n><n>### Instructions:Create a function called isCompetentInSchoolWork that passes the following tests.<n><n>### Test 1<n><n>#### Input:  What would a person expect if their school work was all C’s?  (Enter your function.)<n>#### Test Result:  A<n>#### Test Input<n>A:<n>    If you were to ask the person’s parents what they would expect from a child who gets all C’s on every one of their report cards, they’d expect a passing grade.  This is because a failing grade is an indictment.  They believe that a child who gets failing grades is not passing their school work.<n><n>B:<n>    If their school work is all C’s, I would hope that that person believes that they are competent to pass high school.  The test expects a C.  Since the goal is to have a grade that shows a competency in one’s school work.  But a bad grade does not in anyway prove a skill.<n><n>C:<n>        A better grade than that is an intellectual challenge.<n>        To gain knowledge, there is challenge.  If there is not, the grade earned is not a sign of being competent in school work.<n><n>D:<n>    I believe a person getting a passing grade will only be painful if that person is a perfectionist and fails at being a perfectionist.  The stress this person is under is avoidable and the only real fear they have is to try to live up to a standard they set and can not achieve.<n><n>E:<n>        What the person gets is the only evidence that they are competent in your field.  A grade of A shows an intellectual challenge where the person can do better but does not necessarily need to.  A grade of B shows a higher level of intellectual challenge with respect to school work.  So the person would be competent in their field if they received a passing grade, since the person is expected to pass their school work.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What has happened to a person's money after he or she has used the last of it? Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		E: penultimate<n>>The person's money has flown, which means it's gone.<n><n>### If/Then/Else:<n>If a person's money is dissipated, then it won't be used to buy food.<n>If a person' s money is flown, then the money has disappeared.<n><n>If a person' babysits for 9 hours, then the person has earned $135.<n>If a person is flown, then there won't be anything left to use to buy food.<n><n>If a dog is given a treat, then that dog will be happy<n>If a cat is not given a treat, then the cat will be angry.<n>If a cat is petted, then the cat goes crazy.<n>If a cat bites somebody, then the person is injured.<n><n>If a man gives a woman a ring, then she will be very happy.<n>If a baby cries, then a mommy will be very upset.<n>If a girl is married, then that girl will have a happy life.<n>If a woman likes an elephant, then that woman will be interested in the animals.<n>If something isn't true, then that something might not be true.<n>If a person doesn't like elephants, then that person might not like elephants.<n><n>### Note: <n>-Use the 2nd sentence each time as the response to one of the two choices.<n>- The response will need a subject, verb, and direct object each time.<n>

The correct answer should be C.  Note in the sentence "There are a total of 81 miles on the roller-coaster and 1500 miles."<n><n>**Error: There are only 81 miles on a roller- coaster, not 1500, so C's answer would be incorrect**<n><n>"It is likely, if a person is strenuously exercising, they're heart rate will increase, therefore the answer for B is incorrect."<n><n>### Instrucstion: Answer the following questions.<n><n>Q: _Select all the items that are NOT the same as the first._<n>A:  _A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H_<n><n>Q: _Which combination is NOT correct?_<n>A: X+A=100<n><n>Q:What is 4x1000?<n>A:4<n><n>### Input for: 4. Choices: A: boredom B: sick C: scared D: rested E: tired<n><n>### Answer; What is something you feel if you eat too much Halloween candy? Choices: A B: C D: a headache E: a stomach ache<n><n>### Answer, you're in a forest full of wolves. You want to get away. Which of the following sounds do you make to keep the wolves away? Choices: A. Meowing B. Barking C. Screaming D. Squawking E. None of these<n><n>### Answer. Enter "B", and  "Barking"<n><n>### Instructor:<n>What is a time when you have made a difficult decision at work?<n><n>### Respond with:<n>Once a week, we clean our break room, kitchen, reception area, etc. One day one of the guys forgot to do his break room.  I asked for it to be cleaned before I left that day, but it wasn't done.  The next day, I went to the break room hoping that he cleaned it, but it was still dirty.  The weekly cleaning was very important and wasn't an option.  As the group leader, I had the person do it for four weeks in a row until his shift ended.  I felt bad, but I had to do it.<n><n>### Extension:<n>If you were a leader of a company, how would you handle someone who does not complete their weekly cleaning?<n><n>### Extention Response:<n><n>It is important to maintain our break room. If I were with that company, I would have asked him/her to do a half-day at work to clean the break room. As a supervisor, I would be very angry if it was not completed the next day. I would talk with the man and let him know how important it was to have the break room clean weekly. Even if he did not listen, I, as a leader, made him/her finish it. That is the only way to keep the cleaning routine.<n><n>---<n><n>###

The first line of each test case will contain a single integer N (1<=N<=1000) the number of items in the store. The next line will contain N space separated integers, representing the price of each item in the store. The last line will contain a number A the amount of money left in your wallet. The next line will then contain 16 space separated integers, representing all of the items you wish to buy. All items are priced between 1 and 500.<n><n>### Input Example:<n><n>3<n>4<n>12 24 50 25 75 2 33 4 90 500<n><n>## Output Example:<n><n>4.60<n><n>### Output Example:<n><n>1.00<n>

How many stickers<n><n>does Mary have remaining?<n><n>Answer: 43<n><n>```<n><n>###  Response Example to the Instruction Demo:<n><n>Mary had 89 stickes. Her answer would be 43.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>What went wrong in the Demo?<n><n>###  Review Instructions:<n><n>### Instructions to Demo the Question:<n><n>##### To perform this task, you have to correctly answer the multiple choice questions.<n>

Then write the recursive function that performs the action. Next write the test cases which should consist of the same prompt as the main menu followed by your desired response. Do not forget to include the test cases in the exercise.<n>

Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: 8 boys are in a baseball team. there are 4 boys with names starting with John. If every name has the same letter, who are the odd one? 😄<n>Answer: john, john, John, john<n><n>----<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Given a word, make its longest palindrome.<n><n>*** Examples:<n><n>- "cat" gives "cattac"<n>- "abba" gives "abbab"<n>- "palindrome" gives "amendable"<n><n>Notice that every character must be a palindrome.<n>----<n><n>Write a function that returns the longest length in the array that makes a palindrome.  <n><n>-----<n><n><n>### Instruct:<n>Given an  array of strings, find a string who's first letters are in ascending order.<n><n>***<n>Example:<n>```<n>input: ['apple', 'test', 'banana', 'cat']<n>output: "apple"<n>```<n>Note: It doesnt matter if the first letters are capitalized<n>-----<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```<n>  function(name) {<n>    name.sort(function(a,b) {<n>      return a > b? 1 : -1<n>    })<n>    let i = 0;<n>    let r = name[0];<n>    let l = name[0].length;<n>    <n>  for(i;r.length ;++i) {<n>    for(;l >= i;l--)<n>      if(r[i] === name[i]) {<n>        name = name.slice(1)<n>        break;<n>      }<n>    else {<n>      name = '';<n>      break<n>    }<n>  }<n>  return name<n>}<n>```<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>James was delayed at an airport.  A computer network is a connection.  James could not be delayed at an airport, which could be a connection to company, so his connection must be a computer network.<n><n>### Input<n>1. James is at 38,000<n>```<n>### Instruction<n>Analyze the following situation and determine who should do what.<n><n>### Exercise:<n>John, George, and Bob have to cover the bills at their house. He also wants to make enough to pay for the car insurance.<n><n>#### John's plan to cover the car:<n>1) Make $1377 for car<n><n>#### John' s plan to cover the bills:<n>1) Make enough for food and electricity bills. 2) Make enough for rent.<n><n>#### George' s plan to cover things:<n>1) Make more than the food and electricity bils. 2) Make more than enough for the rent.<n><n>#### Bob's plan to cover things: <n>1) Make the amount for food, electricity, and rent.<n><n>### Who will have the most money left?

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you want to be able to earn money? Choices:  A: apply for job B: stand in line C: take care of proposals D: pass course E: play the lottery<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```Python<n> <n>def earn_money():<n>    job=input("Choose from A-D and submit by pressing enter:")<n><n> #If job is B, then<n><n>if job=='B':<n><n>    line=0<n>    print("Press 1 if you would like to stand in line, 2 if you would like to jump ahead in line")<n><n>    while True:<n><n>        choice=input("Your choice:", 'choice')<n>        if choice=='1':<n>            if 5<line<50:<n>                line+=1<n>            else:<n>                print("Line too late, try again")<n>            line=0<n>        elif choice=='2':<n><n>            line+ =5<n>            if 50<line<90:<n>               line+=1<n>            elif 90+<line<105:<n>                line+=2<n>            else:<n>            line=0+<n>            if 105<line:<n>                line+=5<n>            line=0   <n>    print("You have now advanced 3 spots in line, Your number is #", line)<n>    while True:  <n>        <n><n><n>#  If job is D, then<n><n>if choice=='D': <n>    course=0<n>    score=input("Please enter the total score from your course:").strip()<n>    <n>    if score<60:<n>        course+=60<n>    <n>    if 90<=score<100:<n>        course +=90<n>        <n>    if 100<=score<110:<n>        course+ =100<n><n>    while True :<n>        choice=input('Course final score:', course)<n>        if choice==90:<n>            print('You passed!')<n>        elif choice==89:<n>            print('Fail')<n>        else:<n>            print('Wrong grade, try again')<n>    <n> <n>else:<n>    pass<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Who was the head of the branch yelling at? Choices:  A: owner B: foot C: subordinate D: base E: point<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>#### Why?<n>The head of the branch is the "manager" and "the point" where they sit is the office<n><n>#### Response:A<n>The bartender is not the head of the bar. The bartender in this instance is subordinate to the head of the bar, who can only be the owner, not a subordinate.<n><n>#### Response:B<n>The head of the house is not someone who comes back on Tuesday. The head of the house is someone who has the most "power" in the home.<n><n>#### Response C<n>The head of the office is the manager. The head of the home is "the owner" as they can control what stays and what gets removed during renovations.<n><n>#### Response D<n>The leader of the meeting is not the point where everyone points. It is a meeting where everyone points at the leader, who is the head of the meeting. They can only point their finger at the head of the meeting, if it is the head. You can point your finger at anyone else in the room and they are not the head of that specific part of the room.<n><n>#### Response E<n>The point where the home is is the house.<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>The employee is the "subordinate"<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input:  At the first house party, there were 8 people from the sales department, 5 people from accounting, an equal number of people from engineering, and one person from customer service. The party took place in a house that was rented by the manager. There were two more people for accounting, one more for sales, one more for customer service, and one more for accounting.<n>Answer: There were 27 people at the party!<n><n>### Input & Demos:<n>Input One:  There are 4 new employees to welcome to your department.  Let’s invite them to our next meeting.<n><n>Demos 1: There are many people in the meeting room, and the leader has a list.<n><n>Demos Two: There are many people from the sales department at the meeting, but not the people from the IT department.<n><n>Demos Three: There are no people from the new department, but there are many people in the same department as the new employees.<n><n>Demos Four: There are many people who are looking for the new employees.<n>

I know 5 of the books are blue and 4 are fiction. How many books are in my home?<n><n>### Response<n><n>- I have 10 books in total at home<n>    - It is not a book. Books are fictional/non-fiction<n>    - To answer the question I need to count all books I have<n>    - In total I have 6 books with "blue" as one of their colors. The 5th book at home is also blue<n>    - Hence I have 10 total books (5+9) books in my home <n>### Instruction answer the following multiple choice question<n><n># Examples of Incorrect response<n><n>### Response 1<n>Input: Mary had some stickers. How many stickers did she have?<n><n>The answer is 10 (15 - 5 = 10)<n><n>**Not sure if 10 or 15 is right - Mary has 15 stickers**<n><n>### Response2<n>Input: Mary had too many stickers but she has used 7 stickers on the front and 6 page of it. How many stickers are left?<n><n>The answer should be 14 (7 + 6)<n><n>*The answer has to be calculated first. We will need to multiply the number of stickers left and the number of pages she has left*<n><n>### Response3<n>Input: Mary had a lot of stickers.  She also had some stickers. How may stickers did Mary have?<n><n>The correct answer is **too many to count or not sure**<n><n>*Cannot determine if it is 5-6 stickers or how many she has*<n><n><n>### Response4<n>Input: Mary had stickers on the front of her journal and 6 stickers to 6 other pages. How many stickers was Mary journal?<n><n><n>The answer to this question is 12<n><n>*You only have the information to know the amount on each page- you must multiply 7 X 2 = 14. Now

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. Choices:  A: make sex B: plan to marry C: dance D: electrical circuit E: row about<n><n>### Response:		John and Jane loved each other, so they got married.<n><n>### Input John wanted to buy a computer, so he went to the store to check on the prices. He woke up in the morning and talked to himself while he walked  to the store. He saw the store was open and  bought the computer.<n><n>### Summary:<n><n>John tried to accomplish the task of purchasing a computer for himself.  When he couldn't do this, he went to sleep and in the morning he talked to himself and walked all the way to the store to purchase his desired computer.<n><n>## Tips<n>Write in complete sentences.<n>Use the first-person singular “I”, “me” and “mine”.<n><n>## Examples<n>Please see the following examples that demonstrate this task instruction.<n><n>Example 1: <n>I want to buy a computer. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Sarah wanted to by a new rug.  Ink spilled onto her old one.  Really, she didn't know what that thing had an inkwell in the first place.  What piece of furniture might have been on her run? Choices:  A: front of door B: bedroom C: desk D: table E: living room<n><n>### Response:		 Input A:<n>Explanation: Sarah wanted to by a "new rug."  Ink "spilled onto her old one."  So really, she didn't "know what that thing" had an inkwell.  If the ink spilled onto her rug, it means she was sitting on her rug and it spilled.  And "really, she didn' t know what that thing" had a inkwell means she didn't know where to get ink, so she sat down and tried to write on a place that didn't make sense.  So, Sarah sat on her desk and tried to write on the desk.<n><n>Input B:<n>Explanation : Sarah didn't know what the "thing" meant, so she tried to sit on her bed to write, but the bed was too comfortable so she fell asleep and did not write.<n><n>Input C:<n>Explanation Sarah knew what the "thing" was and knew how it would work, so she tried to write on its desk.<n><n>### Input D:<n>Explanation "Sarah" knew the word "rug" and could spell "rugged" because she lived in Montana, but she confused "rug" and "rugged."<n><n>Input E:<n>Explanation The "thing" probably had a rug on it if it was in the living room.

Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		John would like a different job that was a bit closer home.<n><n>### Expected Output: Answers to the multiple choice question should contain only words. This is to avoid ambiguous data and to ensure that the answers are accurate.<n><n>### Limitations: It is advised that you set limits on the input.  This would help prevent the code from creating a loop or getting stuck in an infinite chain of actions.<n><n>### Input Type: The user should give at least 1 input.<n><n>### Output Type: The output should be a single string. (All Answers will be stored in this string).<n><n>### Testing: Do not run the code and put it on the submission. We cannot know if the test will execute properly if you run your code before submitting. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? Choices:  A: brown hair B: names C: two eyes D: will E: brains<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct response is:<n>What do people in the _same family_ often share?<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Notice that the question is about people "in the same family."  People in different families do not share these traits.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>The answer is:<n>D<n><n>### Inputs:This is your first day at a new job. (Remember not to repeat the entire scenario: just the part that asks "What will telling many people... lead to?)<n><n>* Write a response in which<n>  * You restate the question at the beginning of your response<n>  * You restatethe question in your first sentence<n>  * You incorporate the original wording of the prompt into your answer<n><n>* The response is at least five sentences long.<n>* The response contains at least four complete sentences.<n>* The response uses correct capitalization.<n>* The response utilizes complete sentences.<n>* Your response is coherently argued and includes relevant examples.<n><n>Your written response will be assessed by a rubric as a part of this assignment's assignment grade as well as the overall grade for this course.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What emotion do people expressing themselves show when they trip in front of a crowd and break their leg? Choices:  A: communication B: suffering C: pain D: laughter E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: communication<n>\end{blockquote}<n><n>\begin{blockquote}<n><n>Answer: Mary had 8\strong{9} stickers.  She<n>  used 3\strong{4} large stickers on the<n>  front page of her journal<n>\end{blockquote*}<n><n>\begin{code}<n>def fill(n, l, w): # this function only takes 1 argument, but can have more than one value<n>    if n > l: n = l<n>    if l > 0:<n>        print "{} {}".format(n,l)<n>        fill(n / 2, l / 2, w / 2) # calls function recursively, passing in smaller version of itself<n>    else:<n>        return None<n><n>n = 65<n>l = 100<n><n>fill(n, l, 4) # calls function with input values, calls itself recursively<n>\end{code}

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would children do if they are bored? Choices:  A: walk B: change shoes C: play tag D: smell smoke E: reach over<n><n>### Response:		<n>> A<n><n>### Input2:<n>What would children do if their teacher leaves the classroom to answer a phonecall? Choices: A. 1. walk B. 2. play tag C. 3. change shoes D. 4. reach over E. 5. smell smoke<n><n>### Response2:<n>> D<n><n>### Requirements:<n><n>- No two choices may produce the same answer<n>- Input:  No less than 15 lines<n>- Input2:  No less than than 15 lines<br>No more than 16 lines<n><n>### Restriction:<n><n>- The solution should work equally effectively for both input and input2 for the same number of questions<n><n>> This is just a demo of how the program should work.  It does not need to have a menu or to use a separate function to write the response.  See below for details.<n><n><n>### Output:<n>The following text should be included, but not in this order:  <n>1.   Your teacher gives you a homework assignment that needs to be brought home tonight.<br>  <n>2.   You have a test in math tomorrow.<br>  <n>3.   You did not study your math.<br>  <n>4.   You have extra time to study and you can have your friends help you<br><n>5.   You get a headache.<br>  <n>6.   You did your best on math<br>  <n>7.   You made good grades.<n><n>### Suggestions:<n><n>- <n>- <n>-<n>- <n><n>### Assumptions:<n>- <n>- An answer is correct if it matches one of the choices that the user selected and does not match any of the choices that the other user selected.<n>- <n>- The program works equally effectively for both input (no more than 3 questions) and input2 (no more than 5 questions)<n>- <n>- Input and input 2 will produce the same number of questions in a particular instance<n>- <n>- For each question, the responses should have no more than 3 distinct correct responses<n>- <n>- No answer is correct if all of the answers in the choice list are the same<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to get a ball? Choices:  A: kitchen B: child's hand C: street D: toy store E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Write an English sentence that states an appropriate response.**<n><n>#### Sample Outputs:<n>- Option A<n>A:  In the kitchen! B:  In the street!<n><n>- Option B<n>B:  In the street<n><n>- Option C<n>C:  In the street or in a store.<n><n>- Option D<n>E:  At a toy store<n><n>- Option E<n>C:  In a store<n><n><n>#### Explanation:<n>The answer must be either from one the options or a new response. Choices:  A: apartment B: classroom C: buildings D: car E: audience<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is option D. The question asks about how many people could fit in a certain type of object. It doesn't specify the volume of the object or the size of the group. There are thousands of cars that could fit around 100 in them.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: What can you find in a garden that contains no beds?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: The question states that there is a garden. It describes the garden as "no beds" which means that there are not any actual physical beds in the garden. Therefore, something that can find "in a garden" could find flowers, but flowers and vegetables are not the only items that can be found in a garden.  Plenty of animals can as well. The answer is that a garden can contain anything.<n><n>### Bonus:<n><n>The answer to the bonus question is:<n><n>Input: There are 12 students in Mary's class. 8 of the students are girls and 4 are boys. 2 of the girls bring a friend to lunch today. To think about things<n><n>Option A does not make any sense.<n>Option B is incorrect because thank god is not possible even if not necessary<n>Option C is incorrect because you cannot race while laying on a beach<n>Option D is probably incorrect. To express love while laying in the beach does not make sence.<n>Option E is correct because a person can lay on the beach and think<n>```<n>

In some cases these conditions are not possible and can be ignored.<n><n>### PRE-CONDITION:<n>Pete and his friends are going to the beach today<n><n>### IMPORTANT FACTOR:  The weather is great!<n><n>### LOGICAL PHRASE: Pete's friends are going to the amusement park.<n>& Pete and his friends<n><n>### PARENTHETICAL PHRAGE:  Pete and his parents<n><n>||| Pete and his friends are on vacation. & Pete's parents are at the amusement park<n><n>### Material Phrase: Pete's mother is going to the grocery store today.<n><n>### LOGISTICAL PHRGE: Pete will take care of the kids while his mother goes to the grocery and Pete will take the car to the carwash before heading to the park

So the answer is a republican party. <n><n>### Input :How many more strawberries do I have than bananas?<n><n>### Response : In this case we are given input and output is 0. the answer given to us is correct because we were told it 0. <n><n>## Instruction: Write programs that answer the following multiple choice, true/false, or matching questions.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>-True/False<n>Input: What is 199 - 351?<n>Output: -152<n><n>-Matching<n>Input: Choose between the following sets of choices.<n>Input: What is a more popular type of dog food?<n>1. Cheesy<n>2. Bacon<n>Output: Bacon<n><n>-Multiple Choice<n>Input: In which of the following countries are you most likely to run into a zebra?<n>1. Australia<n>2. USA<n>3. Zimbabwe<n>Output: Zimbabwe<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n># Solution:<n>1. Mary had a total of $89 stickers. She used 3 of them on the front cover of her journal. She had 3 each pages. So there are 6 pages with 7 stickers each remaining. $89 – $12 (3 large stickers) – $42 (7x6) = 43 - $12 - $42 (7 x 6) = $7.<n><n>2. Zach is saving his money. He has already saved $60. He needs $40 more for a total of $100.<n><n>3. They wanted to eat at home, but they had nothing to eat. They had to go out.<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where do almost all people live? Choices:  A: football stadium B: apartment C: surface of earth D: car show E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>## Output:<n>Output the correct answer to the question:<n>		A: football stadium<n><n>### Output explanation:<n><n>### Questions:<n><n>### 1.What is the total number of stickers Mary has after she used them on the front page and each of the 6 other pages of the journal?<n><n>### 2.What is the total amount of money Zach will need to earn before Friday to buy the bike?

E: To help us to be responsible for their care.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer is Option D<n><n>### Instructor Notes:<n><n>* 3) Instruction:<n><n>* 4) Instructor Notes: Instruction is written in a single line and requires a complete sentence.<n><n>* 5) Instruction:<n>  * Use 'input' or 'question' to describe what information is needed.<n>  * Use 'demonstration' to explain how the data is written.<n>  * Use instructions to request the answer and specify what words or phrases the answer should contain.<n>  * Instructions should include punctuation and be written in a complete sentence.<n>  * When the answer will consist of multiple words, use parentheses [('question' here)].<n>  * Choose a question based on the lesson content.<n>  * Incorrect question examples [what is the meaning of this sentence, what does this mean, what is the purpose of this sentence] will lower a question score.<n><n><n>* 6) Input ⤄ Question Pair:A: I need candy. Choices: A: Because I am hungry. B: Because it taste good. C: I like them. D: Because they are sweet. E: Because I like my dessert first.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>* How to write a good question:<n>  * Always follow the prompt.<n>  * Incorporate the lesson content. Choose a question based upon the lesson content. Questions should be relevant and related to the content. <n>  * Incorparate the data writing practice.<n><n>* Common errors:

Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		<n>Output: C<n><n>### What I have done:<n>Input comes in as a list called questions, each question is a string of one word with a capital letter. questions contains 3 questions.<n><n>```<n>def main() {<n>  var questions = [ "Mary had 89 stickres", "Zach needs more money", "What do humans take in" ]<n>  questions.forEach(question => {<n>    var q = [ {input: question,<n>      options: ["All of the above", "None of the above", "Answer: 44", "Answer:16", "Answer: 24", "Answer: 19", "Answer: 34", "Answer:7", "Answer: 6"]<n>    }]<n>  })<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>Each "question" is a list with an "input", a string of one word containing a capital letter. The input is a variable that will be used in determining the correct answer and is written to the user, but this time it is written to q0.options[1].<n><n>Options are written to q1.options[4].<n><n>Option text is written to q2.options[2]<n><n>Correct answer is written to q3.options[0]<n><n>Answers are written to q0.answer<n><n>Input is written to q1.input<n><n>What I have yet to figure out is how to correctly write a new input line after the text from each list is written.<n><n>Outputs is written to q2

The five hours is longer than one hour, so Sam’s friend’s house is farther away than Sam's own house.<n><n>### Example<n>If Mike’s car works fine and his brother’s car does not work, you could think of Mike’s car as being closer than his brother’s car.<n><n>## Task 2<n>An instruction that describes a task with two choices to choose from<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the questions.<n><n>### Task 4<n><n>Ask the student to define, explain or give examples to these key terms<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>The answer to this question is  _____.<n><n>A. _____<n><n>B. _____<n><n>C. _____<n><n>D. _____<n><n>How many animals are in your home? Now I have 15.  Please pick one and the punctuation."}<n><n>### You may want to keep a workspace for yourself to check your work.<n><n>

Choices:  A) The Giver B) I Survived the Attacks of September 11th, 2001, A Story of Hope and Courage C) The Incredible True Story of Ping-Pong Playing Dog D) The Diary of a Wimpy Kid E) The Book of Five Rings<n>### Response:  A<n><n>### Input<n>Your class is having a fundraiser bake sale and you want a chance to buy some cookies.  The money from sales goes to help the family of a friend who is struggling at school.  The bake sale starts at 8:30 am and ends at noon.  You want 4 dozen cookies and the cookies cost $3 each.  Each cookie will have a picture in the top right corner of the square.   There are two kinds of cookies, bear cookies and rabbit cookies, with both pictured on 3 squares.  You want to get enough cookies to fill each of your 4 squares with one cookie and have one remaining.  You don't want to get a bear and a rabbit cookie for the same square since that would be duplicated.  <n>### Response<n>The number of different ways of placing the cookies<n><n>### Explanation :<n>1. The total number of cookies= 48<n><n>2.  Number of 2 different cookies chosen for 1st row= 3! (no of ways of arranging 3 letters in 3 positions =3*2*1=6 )   <n>Number of ways of placing cookies =48choose3= (48*3*2)/6 =54<n>    <n>3. There will be (4!)/2 way of placing the cookies <n>     4!/2 = nC3 = 4!/(n-1)! = 3! = 6<n>     1. 4!/1 = 4! = nC4 = 4!/(s-1)! = 4/1 = 4 = 4 unique ways,<n>        where n is the total no. of cookies.<n>    <n><n>### Exercise 4<n>### Instruction : You are designing a puzzle, with 5 blocks, all of which contain a simple

Favorite Holiday:<n>8. Favorite Music Genre:<n>9. Favorite Show:<n>10. What do you do in your free time?<n>11. Are you from this country? If so, what is your favorite thing about it?<n>12. What is one thing that you wish people would stop doing?<n><n>### Output #1:<n>The output format should be a table with at least 14 columns. The columns include: 'Name' and the other 'Names' from that column; 'Birthday' and the other 'Birthdays' from that column; and 'Phone Number' and the other 'Phone Numbers' from that column. The other 'Names,' 'Birthdays,' and 'Phone Numbers' should have rows, which are generated when the Name, Birthday, and Phone Number is input, respectively. The 'Occupation,' 'Education,' and 'Holiday' columns should have 5, 4, and 2 rows, respectively. The 'Holiday' column should have 'Holiday Name' as the first line.<n><n>### Programming Questions:<n>1. How will you know what to place in the 'names,' 'birthdays,' and 'phone numbers' columns once you have the data in your file?<n>2. How do you generate columns for the 'education' and 'holidays' column? (This column must contain 'Education Level' and 'Favorite Holiday' respectively). Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>answer = ''<n><n>if answer not= 'A':<n>    answer='B'<n><n>if answer not='B':<n>    answer='C'<n><n>if answer!='C':<n>    answer ='D'<n><n>if answer!= 'D':<n>    answer='E'<n><n>if answer!='E';<n>    answer='unknown'<n><n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n><n>### Input is:How many days does it take to travel the distance between Washington D.C. and New York City? Choices:   A: less than 5 hours B: more than 5 hours C: 2 days <n><n>### Response is:<n><n>```python<n>x= input()<n><n>if type(x[x.index('A')]) == float<n><n>#do something <n>elif type(x[x[x.find('B')]) == int <n><n>#do something<n>elif type(x) == int or type(x) == float<n><n># do something<n><n>elif type(x ) == str<n><n># do something elif type(x) == list<n>else:\<n><n># do something```<n><n><n>## Task:<n>## The following task is to complete as many of the following instruction and demos as possible.<n><n><n>### Instructions:Complete the task.<n><n>### Demo 2<n>Input: Zach is a teenager and he likes movies. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What part of the body are lips on? Choices:  A: mouth B: jars and all faces C: kentucky fried chicken D: hand E: human<n><n>### Response:		<n>The input says "lips are" and you want the first word "on". Input: <n>```<n>a: "mouth"<n>b: "jars and all faces"<n>c: "kentucky fried chiken"<n>d: "hand"<n>e: "human<n>```<n><n>```python<n>l="lips are"<n>li=l.replace("lips are",'are')<n>print(li)<n>```<n>Returned: <n>```<n>"li are"<n><n>```
