E: the show is on in _______ minutes Bick and Movie, they are my choice.<n><n>### Response<n>How much does this movie cost me?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Create a function named is_a_science_genius (argument). The argument is an array. The function should return "no" if the values of the array do not add to 100. The function should return the phrase "you are a science genius!" if the array is empty or the array add up to 100 or more. The values should be the number of elements in the array.<n><n>### Demo<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>3. This program should read in a number and it should tell the user if the number is prime or not and then print "YES" or "NO"<n><n><n>### Insttructions:<n><n>### What to do:<n>-   Use the following variables<n>    -   counter for loop count<n>    -   current_prime for the current prime number<n>    -   current for the number read<n>-   Ask for and read a number from the user and store in current_prime<n>-   Loop while current_prime is less than or equal to the number read<n>- 3.  Decrease the current_prime by 1 and compare to the read number<n>    - If the current_prime is greater than 2 is  not prime<n>    - Else:<n>        - print "YES, the number is prime" if the current_prime is prime<n>        - print "NO! the number entered is not prime"<n>-   End loop<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input number:<n><n>    "17"<n><n>### Output:<n>    YES, the number is prime.<n><n><n>## Instructions:<n>    <n>1. Use this code to read in any string of characters. The characters must start and end with

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Her balloons cost 50 cents each to buy and she sells them for a total of $2.  She's made 150 balloon sales so far.  How much money has she made today?  <n>Answer: $65 (150 * 2 - 10)  <n><n><n>### Input:`Alex has 2 dollars saved from his allowance and he has 3 dollars a month of allowance.  The rate of interest at the bank is 3%.  If he saves his money for 5 years, how much money will Alex have in the bank on his 20th birthday?'<n><n>### Response:`According to the given information Alex will have (2 * 16.5 x  3) + (3 * x x 16.5) = 103.25 dollars in bank on his 21st birthday.'<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If I screw a chain ring onto something, what am I fixing? Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>if choice == 'Screw':<n>    if input == 'A' or input == 'B':<n>        print('Necklace!')<n>    if input =='C' or input == 'D':<n>        print('Tool box!')<n>    if choosen!= input or input == 'E' and input!= 'C':<n>        if choosen.startswith('C'):<n>            print('Computer!')<n>        else:<n>            print('Motorcycle!')<n>else:<n>    print('None of the above!')<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>Choose one of the following choices:  A: necklaces B: wall outlet C: tool box D. computer  E; motorcycle<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n><n>

The bank would give him $52 more than he needs to deposit in the bak to use.  How much money can he have in his wallet if he wants to deposit the money he needs to the bank?<n>### Demonstanation:<n>The player had $3.  The bank gave him 1000-52=848 more than he needs to put in the bank, so player is 52-848= -796.  Now he could still have $796-3-52= 327.2 more in his wallet.<n><n>### Answer Input<n>> The player decided to deposit $132.80 in the bank, and the bank did exactly that.<n>> Input<n>> The player can either have the extra money or keep the extra in he bank.<n><n>### Analysis<n>### Input:<n>If the number is at least 10, then sum the current number and the remainder of the division.<n>If not, then multiply the current number with 2.<n><n>### Description<n>The function `numberToRoman` returns a string with all characters in lowercase.<n><n>### Code<n>This works fine:<n>````javascript<n>function numberToRoman(num) {<n>  var a = "m",<n>    b = "l", c = "x", d = "c", e = "d", f = "lv", g = "iv", h = "xv", i = "
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What treatment might an old time doctor have tried to accomplish with leeches? Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n><n>What treatment might an old-time doctor have tried to accomplish using leeches?  Choices:  <n>A: heart transplant  <n>B: distance himself  <n>C: perform surgery  <n>D: study medicine  <n>E: let blood<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>We have to separate the instructions and then use that to help make the response.<n><n>The first instruction and the first part of the question can be separated into:<n><n>>What treatment might an old timed doctor have tried to accomplish?<n><n>and the first part of the instructions will tell us the question.<n>The next part of the instructions will give us the choices in which we can answer the question.<n><n>Let us start off with a method called: **Sentence Splitting**<n><n>Since it is a Sentence, it will start with the word "WHAT"<n>"What treatment might an old -time doctor have tried to acomplish?"<n><n>If we make one change, then it will be the Sentence will begin with the other question part, "How much more money"<n><n>"How much more money does Zach Need to earn?"<n><n>Now if we keep following the Sentence Splitting instructions, then it will become:<n>"How much more will Zach need to earn?"<n>If we do this to our question, then it becomes:<n>" How much more will Zach need let?"<n><n>Then we can use our **Punctuation Clue - Colon** to help us with our next sentence to make the response.<n>In our question, after we ask how much more, we use a colen. We will use that to begin this sentence we will be making.<n><n>"Zach needs let"<n><n>We then need to use this as a sentence which can then be a part of our response to let.<n><n>Zach needs to let blood<n><n>This is a very important sentence to note, as it is something Zach needs to do.<n><n>Therefore, our response is :<n><n>"Zach Needs to Let Blood."

The average high for the summer in 3 degrees higher than the average summer high. The winter high in 5 degrees lower than the average high for spring. The average high in autumn is 4 degrees lower than the average summer high, and the winter average low is 1 degree lower than the average spring high. For what season does the average high occur?<n><n>Answer: Autumn, since the average high in the summer is 3 degrees higher than all the other seasons.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>```bash<n>echo "Your grandfather's birthdays"<n>echo "Your grandmother's birthdays" # the response<n>echo "The snake was a....."   # Input<n>echo "The squeaky wheel gets.." # Input<n>echo "Mary had 80, what.."<n>echo "Zach is saving his savings, how much..?" # Input<n>echo "Your grandfaddher's birthdays:.." # Input<n>```<n><n>## Hints<n><n>### Input 1: Your grandfather's bithdays<n><n>I looked up data for the United States for a while, and realized that the average birthday is March 23.<n><n><n><n>### Input2: your grandmother's Birthdays<n><n>My grandmother has to be older than my grandfather, so I can't get an average birthday. Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		Cats typically meow.  A cat's meow can be broken down into two groups of sounds, those being the call or greeting and the response or acknowledgment.  Cats greet each other, their owner, other animals, as well as humans by using this meow call.  Cats then respond to other cats greeting or acknowledging them by meowing back.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input and Response:Cats can meow, but they will also have several other unique sounds that they can make.  Cats hiss to put other animals on notice, to say no, and to warn off danger by showing their sharp teeth.  Cats also growl and grunt when they are playful or upset to get a human or another animals attention.  Cats purr, which is thought to be the cat way of showing contentment.  Finally, cats cackle, yowl, and yelp when they are happy or scared.<n><n>### Question type 1<n><n>### Type Answer<n><n>### Instructions:Write the sentence to the right.<n><n>### What would you normally expect a dog to say?<n><n>### Question 2<n><n>### Type of question<n><n>### Instrument:<n><n>### Instruct the following:<n><n>### Show this question to the following person:<n><n>### Input Type<n><n>### Response Type<n><n><n>### Type answer to question 2

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Why is this person not listening to music? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: relaxation C: deafness D: bored E: calm<n><n>### Response:		<n>C)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Description:<n>I am going to add three new fields (or variables/properties) to user data. The new fields will be type of user, the amount they've paid for each month of their subscription, and how much their discount is each month. In this exercise, you will take that request and code a method to make the new fields available for the userData that I've already set!<n><n>### Instructors Note:<n>1) Use the UserData class that is included below, OR create one similar to it.<n>2) The code will use those three attributes: type, paid, discount.<n>3) The method will return a new instance of UserData with the new fields.<n>4) I will send your UserData class.<n>  5) I need this method to be able to be called on UserData objects anywhere.  I don't care how it can be called from outside the "model" part of the App.<n><n><n>### Inputs<n> - The type of user.<n> ```javascript<n> var userData = new UserData("type: 1");<n> ```<n> - How much the user has paid.<n> ```javascript<n> userData.paid = 95; // 2 months at $84.99<n> ```<n> - The discount for a user with that type.<n> ```javascript<n> if(userData.type == 0) {<n>  userData.discount =.2;<n> }<n> ```<n><n>### Output<n> ```javascript<n> - A new UserData instance that contains the information from the inputs.<n> ```<n><n>## Instructor note on how the instructor can use the result of this exercise<n> ```javascript<n> var usr = new UserData("");<n> // or<n> var usr = require('../models/userData').newInstance(myType).myDiscount(myValue);<n> ```<n><n>## Class Code:<n> - ```javascript<n>function UserData(type){<n>  var props={};<n>  props["type"] = type+"";<n>  props["paid"] = 0;<n>  props["discount"] = 0.75;<n>  this.__proto__ = data;<n>  this.discount = 0.7;<n>  this['type'] == 4;<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n>function myFunction(e) {<n>  myAni = e.target.value, myAni === "Ferret's"? myAni : 'Ferret's trousers', console.log(myAni); // 'Ferret'<n>}<n>```<n></details><n><n>### Input<n>The above Instruction does not have a value for the variable `myAni`.  How should you fill in the blank to provide your answer?<n><n>The above Instruction has a value for the `myAni` variable.  You can either provide the answer with that value or give the answer with the correct value for `myAni`.<n><n>### Input-output Question Instructions:<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Solution:<n>```javascript<n>function solution(e) {<n>    'use strict'<n>    myAni = e<n>    if (myAni === 'Ferret' ||'s trousers') return console.log(myAnni +'is Ferret')<n><n>  }<n>  let ferret = 'Ferret' && 'Ferret' =='s trousers'? 'Ferret' : 'Ferret trousers';<n>  console.log(ferret);<n>}<n>```

Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n><n>if (input=="A") {answer== "crowd"}<n>if (input=="B") {answer== "high school"}<n>if (input!="C") {answer== "a theater"}<n>if (input == "D") {answer = "Somewhere"}<n>else if (input == "E") {answer=="city"}<n>else answer=="something"<n>```<n>or<n>```javascript<n><n>case (input=="A") :<n>if (input=="a") {answer=="crowd"}<n>else answer=="a"<n>break;<n>case (input=="B") :<n>if (answer=="A" or input=="C") answer=="high school"}<n>else answer=="B"<n>break;<n>else answer=="C"<n>break;<n>}<n>else answer=="D"<n>break;<n><n>else answer=="E"<n>break;<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Sunday is the day of the week that has 3 letters. The dog hides under the house.<n>2. The cat is on the sofa.<n>3. The baby is sleeping.<n><n>In a survey, 33 out of 52 students responded that the best part of school is recess. Write a program that asks the user to enter a single-character array that represents a two-digit number. Use a nested loop to print the array letter by letter.<n>### 2. Write a program that generates three randomly chosen integers by looping with the for statement. Test your program by selecting a value for i that exceeds the total number of elements in the array. Change it, test again.<n>### 3 Write a program that takes in single -character words from a user on stdin. Use a while loop to print each word once (to show that the letter has been entered more than once, the same word will print out multiple times).<n>### 4. Write a program that outputs all the ways that you could divide 12 into quarters, using a nested switch statement and then calling one of four functions in each case.<n>### 5. Write a program that demonstrates how variable initialization should work. The program should include an initialization statement before the nested for loop.<n>### 6. Write a program that prints an array with 10 elements that all have the value 5. The entire array should be written out as a single string, separating each element with a comma.<n>### 7.Write a program that prints out all of the different ways to form a four-letter word from alphabetical characters. A letter can only be included once. Also, the four letters must be unique characters, not repeats of previously printed letters.<n>### 8. Write a program that makes use of variables whose values are strings. The program should use the switch statement to accept input in the following ways:<n>- Input a series of numbers to add to a running total.<n>- input a series of negative numbers, which decrease the running total.<n>- Input letters A, B, or C to specify which array to use.<n>The program should then go through a for loop that prints the array as long as the length of the array is greater than 0.<n>### 9. Write a program that prompts the user to

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. NHQ<n>2. ZUJ<n>3. JTG<n><n>### Instruct:<n>The instructions below need to be completed using these letter groups as the instructions indicate.<n><n>The letters need to be arranged in the exact order of the numbers that describe the letters.<n><n>Example:<n>If you have NHQ (1356) in the first spot, then there needs to be ZUJ (1523) in the second spot, JTG (5234) in the third spot, and ____ (____) in the last spot.<n><n>Input: The instructions in this exercise have been left in your school's mailbox.  On the top of the instructions is a list of letters and numbers. If you can correctly identify what the letters and numbers represent, you will understand how to construct a staircase.  The instructions for constructing staircases are listed below.<n><n>### Input List<n><n>1. NH<n>2. ZU<n>3. JT<n><n>### Instuctions<n><n>1. Place first stair NHQ at first step.<n>2. Place second stair NHJT in space to the right.<n>3. Place third stair ZUJTG at space to the left of JT and at the end of stair NHJUT.<n><n>Input: How to construct a stair<n>Instructions:<n><n>1. Create stair made of 4 steps.<n>2. First step is first stair made of NHJ.<n>3. Second step is second stair made of HQ. <n>4. Step on first and second (in order) and step three is ZU.<n><n>### Response<n><n>_3 steps needed_<n><n><n><n>### Add one more item to this exercise<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### Question:<n>How can you know if someone is telling the truth?<n><n>#### Input List:<n><n>4. Eyes are red<n>5. Breathing is fast<n>6. Pupils dilated<n>

(They put their pockets in their back pants.)<n><n>### Instuctions:The answer to each question begins with the letter 'd.'<n><n>### Instructon:What is one reason for people keeping their wallets in their pants?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Answer: Because they can.<n><n>### Demo2:<n>Answer: One of the reasons is because they can.  (It is just a guess.)<n><n>### Demo3:<n>Answer: Because it is common.  (Or commonplace.)<n><n>### Input:- How many animals can a camel store?  (Hint: use "if..." statements.)<n><n>Answer: If it is a pack.  There are 100 or more.<n><n>### Input2:- How many years can the average person jump in one year?<n><n>Answer: There are 11 months.  (Not exact.  It can depend on the number of times they jumped.)<n><n>### Challenge:- Give a definition to the word'mammoth'.<n><n>Answer: I can't think of any.<n><n>### Answer2:- Yes, I can!  It's the biggest elephant that lives in my imagination.<n><n>### Challenge:Create a program that tells me how old my dad must be if I'm twice his age and he's 68 years old.  (The answer does not require division.)<n><n>### Answer: The first thing you need to know is how old you were when he had you.  Your dad had me twice his age; I turned 40 about 5 years ago.  If my dad is 68, he was born some time between 1955 and 1957.  (He turned 15 in 1973)  Since you were born twice his age he was born just a bit before 1970.<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Include input instructions and expected output information (if required). (2 to 5 points) **<n>Input = Mary had 89 Stickers. She used 3 large Stickers on the front page and 7 Stickers each to 6 others pages of her journal.<n>    Let x be the amount of stickers remaining. (assume x>=0)<n>    Input<n>    Mary had 89<n>    She used 3 large<n>    She used 7 small<n>    Input<n>    How many stickers does mary have remaining<n>    Let x be remaining<n>    Mary had 44 stickers remaining (after giving away one at a time)

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she wanted to get good grades? Choices:  A: feel proud B: try to learn C: need assistance D: thank god E: read alot<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input:(Read) The student made "A" or "B" on each quiz.  One of her finals scores was 93.  This was a cumulative score.  It was the total of her quiz average. The student had scored a total of 97% on quizzes in math class.  She wrote 136 math problems and 25 were unanswered. She had no problem areas. Her grade was  %96% for the last week of school until the end of the year.<n><n>### Response:(Answer) Her best subject overall was Math.<n><n>### Input:"How many cats are in a litter?"  Choices:  D: 5 E: 4 F: 3 G: 2 H: 1<n><n>### Response:"Cats come in litters, not the other way around."<n><n>### Input"What year was the Battle of Little Bighorn fought?"  Choices:    A: July 27, 1876 B: July 10, 1976 C: July 3, 1873 D: June 17, 1899<n><n>### Response"The Battle of Little Bighor was fought in 1876."<n><n>### Instrucation:(Cont.) How much would you estimate is the total amount of money needed to buy what?<n><n>### Input&Response:(Calculation) The total amount of money needed is $3500<n><n>### Insturction:(Cont'ed) Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demoction:<n>A: When is it most cost effective to buy a car?<n><n>### Response": When you have thousands for a down payment and at a low interest rate."<n><n>### Demoption:<n>Answer: When you have tens of thousands for a deposit and at a low credit rate"<n><n>### Demotion:<n>B: What kind of car do most people want to buy?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Answer: A good looking, reliable and low cost to own car"<n><n>### Input- What do most people want to do? Write a subroutine that would handle the request.<n><n>Expected Output:<n>If the program receives input “10” as the number of bags requested (from 1 to 30), the response should be “OK”. If the input is anything other than “10”, the program should respond with “What number of bags do you need?”<n><n>### Instrumental variable test:<n>If the number requested is any number from 1 to 3, then this indicates that the user doesn’t know the cost of one bag, or that their calculations are off, resulting in the need for a prompt (the response should be “What number of baskets do you need”).<n><n>If the number requested by the user is 31 or 32, then the program should respond with a friendly message asking whether the user wants a small or a large sieve. Otherwise, it should respond with a message stating “Small or Large?” If the user requests a small sieve  the program should respond with the OK! If the user requests a large sieve, the program should respond with OK.<n><n>### Example code:<n><n>### Output:<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would people be looking at some things which can move, but are not moving? Choices:  A: football stadium B: surface of earth C: car show D: opera E: movie<n><n>### Response:		<n>   <n>   <n>   <n>### Input: What two things can an artist tell about a building based solely on its silhouette? Choices:  Two walls Four columns Five sides Six sides<n><n>### Response<n><n>   <n>   <n><n># Part B<n>### Input:  Two days straight, Mary was reading her book The Wizard of Oz. She read a lot of words and a lot of chapters. She didn't use any of them when telling her dad about the story the next day. How many words did Mary read?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If Mary read 8 chapters, then she'd read 8x100 words each chapter.  That's 800 words.  If she read 3,000 total words, then she'd use three chapters.  Therefore, 8 chapters = 800 words and 3000 words = 3chapters.  I read 8 chapters and my total word count was 10,500.  So, 3 = how many other chapters Mary read.<n><n>### Input:: What's the most likely place where you'd see a clock? Choices: 1) your bedroom 2) your office 3) outside 4) on the plane 5) in a cafe<n><n><n>### Response::<n><n>   <n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Then, count the number of spaces, and count each character in the line that follows the closing parenthesis.  <n><n>## **Syllable Count**<n>Input: You can't have just one.<n>Output: 3<n><n>## **Programming Example (in English)**<n>```javascript<n>var sentence = "You can't have just ons.";<n>var words = sentence.split(" "); // words is an array of the words used in sentence.word['h':1};<n>var spaces = words.length - 4; // A sentence can only have four spaces.<n><n>for (var i = spaces; i > -1; i--) {<n>  var chars = words[sentence.length - i -2];<n>  var count = 0; // Keep track of the number of characters in the array.<n>  var countWord = 0; // A counter to track the count of every character of a word in the sentence.<n>  for (var j = 0; j < chars.length; j++) {<n>   if (chars[j] ==" ") {count++;};<n>   console.log(chars[j]);<n>  }<n>}<n><n>var i

Choices:  A: go shopping B: generous C: earn money D: have money E: gift buyer<n><n>### Response:		I think the correct answer is a gift buyer because if you are known to buy presents for other, then you need to buy a lot of money and you do not have a lot of money.<n>For the answer B is wrong. If you are called generous than you would give money to help your friends instead of receive money from your friends to buy presents.<n>For the answer C is also wrong. It is not likely to be called the person who earn money because they would not have enough money to buy presents and they do not know how much the present is for the other people.<n>For the choice D is also wrong, because in the definition of giving a present it would also be call as a gift buyer.<n>For the choice A is also not correct, because the definition of go shopping does not mentioned buying presents.<n><n>### 1. Choices:  A: hospital bed B: legroom C: spinning wheel D: grand piano E: rhythm<n><n>### Response:		A<n>- A spinning wheel is a device used to spin thread or yarn by spinning horizontally with the help of a foot-treadle. It is called a spinning wheel because the wheel is part of a mechanism used to set the twist in thread when its single strand is pulled through it.<n><n>### Inputs:She had four different dresses in her closet, she had six different shirt and seven different pairs of shoes.  how many pieces of clothing and accessories did she have?<n><n>### Response Input: <n>- She had 16 pieces of clothing and seven pieces of accessories.<n>        16 (dresses) + 7 (shoes) + 7(shirts) = 16 + 7 + 7 = 16+7+7 = 16 +(7+7)=16+14=20 20-16=4 which means 4 times 7 = 4 X 7 = 28 <n>- So, in total, there are 28 pieces of clothing and shoes.<n><n>### Notes:<n>- 1. Chang's in a single day is an even number.  The number of people who eat there on a Wednesday is an even number.<n><n>Answer: Even <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program that replaces the text in a comment, which should consist of multiple lines, each line beginning with the '#'. If the text cannot be deleted, the program should print the text and continue.<n><n>### Code:<n>```<n># This is line 1 of the comment  <n># This is line two of the comment  <n><n># this is a comment with multiple lines<n><n>```<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>#import pylint;<n><n>f=open( sys.argv[1],"r" )<n>txt=f.read()<n><n>no_of_lines = txt.count('#')<n>comment = txt.split('#', 0)[1]<n>comment = comment.replace('\"','')<n><n>if no_of_lines == 2:<n>    comment1 = comment.split(',')<n>else:<n>    if no_of_lines > 3:<n>        print comment<n>    if no_lines >= 0:<n>        comment = '''# This is line '' + int(no_of_lines) +' of the comment<n># and this is line ''' +comment1[int(no_of_line)] + ''' of the comment (''' + str(len(comment1))+''')''' <n><n>f.close()<n><n>if no_lines==2:<n>    no_lines=0<n>    f=open( sys.args[1],"r")<n>    no_lines = f.read().split('\n').count('#')<n>    f.close()<n>    comment<n>```<n>### Instruction<n>The program should print an int with a description of the number it represents.<n>### Solution<n>```<n>import lxml<n>from string import ascii_letters<n><n># This line returns

Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E: reproduce.<n><n>### Explanation:  If procreation is successful, the baby is created- reproduction has occurred.<n><n>### Input 2 :There are 3 pets at the Pet store: a squirrel, a chick, and a rabbit The cost of the squirrel is $22, the chick is $16, and the rabbit is $12. The store wants to make a profit, so sell each pet for $14.00.  If the sales price for the animals must always be $14.0 how much will the store make?<n><n>### Response 2 :The store will make a profit of $50.00.<n><n>### The first equation would be <n><n>$22 +2 = 14$<n>or $22 - 2 = 14$.<n><n>As you add 2 back and add 2 to the price, it remains the same.<n><n>The $22 - 6 = 16$, so $22 + 6 = 14$. Since there is no loss and no gain, the store ends up at a profit of $5$.<n><n>### The second equation  should be <n>$16 - 2 = <n><n>### Since the pets are sold at their cost, and the cost is less than the sale price, all the money will go towards profit.<n><n>$$16 - 22 = 6$$<n><n>The next equation will be <n>$14 + 4 = <n><n>##$14 + 12 = <n><n>or $14 - 12 = 7$<n><n>These are all options. <n><n>### Examplar 3:What will be the first 2 letter's of the word 'CAPITAL' if it were rearranged in alphabetical order?<n><n>### Exemplar 4:There are 4 people.  Their names are: George, Henry, Isabella, and Lucy.  Each person lives in a different year.  Each person will tell one year of his birthday.  What is George's birthday?<n><n>### Answers:<n>>George's Birthday is 2018.<n><n>### One solution for this

Your program should either ask for a single value, perform a mathematical operation on the value that is inputted, and display the output value, or perform a function using the input value in a predefined manner. <n><n>### Solution:<n>A function is a block of code that can perform specific work. Functions are a group of lines of code that we usually put together as a single block with a unique name that we can call back easily.<n><n>For example, we might have a function named'my_total' with a line like this <n>`my_total += my_a + my_b;` if we wanted our function to do some math, we can just call `my_total` anytime after it is defined. <n><n>Our function can be as simple as printing hello world:<n>**Hello World Function in Python**:<n>```python<n>def my_total(my_a,my_b):<n>    print ('my_total() function')<n>    return my_a+ my_b<n>```<n>**Hello World Function Output**:<n>![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73568345/136635523-83e224aa-a8d9-4091-b6d6-12e957f6fa94.png)<n><n>In this instructure we will create a function in karel where the function's parameter will be a single variable from either 'input' or 'output'.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In Karel the Robot:<n><n>A single input function is one that accepts a single variable from the 'input' and performs a mathematical operation on it. <n><n>A single output function is one that takes a single input from the 'output' and performs a mathematical function on it.<n><n>### Example:<n>For example, we can implement a single input or single output function where we take a single number from the 'input' (like the number of hours, minutes, or seconds) and then perform a mathematical operation on it (adding 1, multiply it by 720 or so).<n><n>After performing an action with 'output', we can

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where can you see a mammoth in NYC? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input<n>Which of the following is not a valid date format?<n>Choices:  A: (MM)YYYY  B: (YYYY-MM)YYYY C: (MM/DD/YYYY) D: (0001-01-01)E: (1-9-YY) <n><n>### Response<n>B<n><n>### Input <n>What was the first month? Choices:  M: January B: February C: March D: April<n><n>### Response <n>A<n><n>## A: What would the code look like with four lines?<n><n>```python<n># Create a variable to store the list of numbers<n>num_list = []<n># For loop<n>for i in range(0, 10, 2):<n>    num_list.append(4 * i)<n>```<n><n><n>## B: What would the code above look like using a list comprehension?<n><n>```python <n># Create a variable. <n>num_list = [4 * i for i in range(0,10, 2),<n># create a list comprehension<n>len(4*i, i in range(0 to 10, -2), num_list)<n>```<n><n>## C: Write a code that creates a list with an element "hello" repeated 50 times.<n><n>```python<n>list = ['hello'] *50<n>```<n><n>## D: Convert a list of numbers (eg. [1, 1, 1,... 19, 19]) into a list of elements that occur once in the list.<n><n>```python 	<n># Create variable <n>list = [1, 10,..]<n># Split the long list into even parts and append each part to a list. <n>lists = [i for i in range(len(list)/2)]<n>```<n><n>## E: Create a list that contains all positive even numbers after 2.<n><n>```python	<n>list_elems = [2, 4, 6, 8...28]<n>```<n><n>## F: Using a list, print odd numbers until the highest odd number is reached<n><n>```python 3<n>odd = [3, 5, 1, 7]<n>    for i in odd :<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The jar was plastic, just like most of the stuff in the kitchen.  John preferred glass, and wished he was somewhere else.  Where does he want to be? Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n>* if John wishes to be anywhere else => "A:  anywhere else"<n>* if John wishes he was someplace else, then that place is not his home =>  "E:  garbage dump"<n>* if John preferred glass, then any other materials are not desired: "B:  anywhere else" "C:  everything"<n>* if John wished to be anywhere else, then that is not his home => "E:  garbage dum"<n><n>### Input : Choices:  A : Pure B : Woo C : All D : All Pure<n><n>### Response :<n>* if no one wants to be anywhere else,  they want to be pure  "All: Pure"<n>* if pure comes before anything, then only pure will be desired.<n>* if everyone wants to be pure, then they don't want to be anything else "All: Pure  "<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy a glass of wine? Choices:  A: art show B: basement C: bar D: church E: basement<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If 'A' is selected, then answer "At an art show!"<n><n>If 'B' is selected, then ask the user to repeat the question with a different choice.<n><n>Repeat until one of the provided responses are selected.<n><n><n>### Input:"How do you get on the bus?"<n><n><n>### Response:"To get on the bus you place your backpack on your back, walk, or fly to the bus stop.<n><n>To get off the bus stop, you can take the bus or walk."<n>"If the answer is a valid answer, print the answer."<n>"Otherwise, if the answer is not a valid answer, print out the instruction again."<n><n><n>### Instructor Notes:<n>* This code is very similar to a previous program, I have just replaced some commands that were not working.<n>* The input and answer of the program is very similar to a multiple choice quiz question.<n>* This program is not checking which answer the user entered. The program is printing out a random answer that could be the correct answer or incorrect answer.<n><n>### Author:Lacey Lehmann<n><n>### Student:Megan Sears<n>
